entries: Esta habitación está cómodamente amueblada para habitantes de tamaño humano.
Una gran sección de la pared helada frente a la puerta se desvanece durante 1 minuto al tocarla, exponiendo esta sala a los elementos. Más allá de la pared hay una plataforma de aterrizaje exterior.

entries.name: 15. Kitchen

entries: La escena es un puro caos: docenas de kobolds picando, mezclando, llevando sacos de ingredientes y removiendo grandes calderos. Podría ser un laboratorio de alquimia o una cocina; con los kobolds cocinando, es un poco difícil estar seguro.

Veinte {@creature Kobold||kobolds} están aquí, preparando comida para los demás habitantes del castillo. La cocina está repleta de enormes bandos de ternera, ovejas enteras, cofres llenos de pescado seco y enormes cantidades de tocino, cebollas, judías, etc.

En una cornisa sobre la refriega hay un {@creature griffon}. La criatura es la mascota de {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} y se encarga de que los kobolds se comporten. Cada vez que se produce una pelea, un grito desde arriba hace que los kobolds vuelvan a la fila. El grifo también protege a los kobolds si son atacados.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Un minucioso registro de la cocina revela pequeños cofres de pimienta negra, canela y nuez moscada. Cada uno de ellos pesa 2 libras, pero su contenido vale 130 gp en total.

entries.name: 16. Upper Courtyard
entries: El patio superior es el principal lugar de aterrizaje de dragones, wyverns y hechiceros voladores cuando el castillo está en el aire. Durante el día, {@dice 2d6} {@creature Ogre||ogres} practican aquí su lanzamiento de jabalina. Por la noche, el patio está ligeramente oscurecido por la niebla (hasta una altura de 30 pies) y patrullado por los {@creature vampire}, {@creature Sandesyl Morgia|HotDQ} (ver {@area area 18|23f|x}).
Altas y esbeltas torres y muros de hielo encierran un patio azotado por el viento.

Los personajes que aterricen aquí deben estar preparados para mostrar un estandarte o una señal del culto inmediatamente; de lo contrario, los ogros o el vampiro de guardia darán la alarma y los atacarán. Los ogros del área 20 investigan cualquier disturbio fuerte en el patio.

entries.name: Developments
entries: Si los personajes llegan disfrazados o se abren paso rápidamente por el patio, son llevados a encontrarse con {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} el gigante de las nubes (si es capturado por los ogros), o {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} (si es capturado por el vampiro).

entries.name: 17. High Blue Tower

entries: Esta torre de hielo azul pálido es del color del cielo en un día de invierno. Sus escasas ventanas brillan como un espejo o un cristal.

La puerta de esta torre está equipada con una cerradura de hierro, y {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} lleva la única llave. La cerradura se puede forzar con {@item thieves' tools|PHB} y un chequeo de Destreza DC 15 exitoso. Dos ogros armados con jabalinas, rocas y una balista vigilan en lo alto de esta torre. Tienen largos rollos de cuerda que utilizan para subir y bajar por el exterior de la torre.

El interior de la torre es un cilindro hueco de 90 pies de altura, sin escaleras ni escalas para llegar a la cima. Cualquier criatura del interior de la torre que pronuncie la palabra de mando "Esclarotta" es teletransportada instantáneamente a {@area area 21|25f|x}.

entries.name: Developments
entries: Si los dos ogros que vigilan en lo alto de esta torre comienzan a disparar la balista o a dejar caer algunas rocas, llaman la atención de los guardias ogros, los cultistas y otros en los terrenos principales del castillo y el patio con bastante rapidez. La alarma se da en cuanto cualquier ogro grita.

entries.name: 18. Crumbling Tower
entries: Esta torre tiene casi 30 metros de altura, pero está en mal estado. Hay dos entradas: una puerta en la base de la torre que no se puede abrir (ver más abajo), y una puerta que funciona y que está conectada a un balcón de hielo que se está desmoronando a 75 pies sobre la base de la torre.

Esta antigua torre parece estar desmoronándose. Las ventanas se han sellado con hielo y se han formado grietas en las paredes y el tejado. Un balcón de hielo esculpido abraza uno de los lados de la torre, 75 pies por encima de su base.

Esta es la torre de la {@creature vampire} {@creature Sandesyl Morgia|HotDQ}, una elfa lunar que se unió al Culto del Dragón mucho antes de convertirse en no-muerta. Es miembro de la vieja guardia y estuvo presente mucho antes de que Severin tomara el mando. Si se le da la oportunidad, habla de haber servido bajo el mando de Sammaster y de haber matado dragones para criarlos como dracoliches, lo que todavía considera "el verdadero camino". Odia a los nuevos líderes de la secta, pero se ve obligada por las circunstancias a trabajar con ellos.

Sandesyl está activa sólo de noche y merodea por los patios superior e inferior en las horas nocturnas, vigilando atentamente a los guardias ogros solitarios o a otros que puedan servir de comida. Cuando se enfrenta a más enemigos de los que puede manejar, convoca a dos {@creature vampire spawn} (consortes elfos lunares) como refuerzos. Estos {@creature vampire spawn} acechan en el piso superior de la torre.

La torre necesita urgentemente ser reparada. El hielo agrietado y desmenuzado proporciona abundantes asideros, lo que permite escalar las paredes de la torre con un chequeo de Fuerza ({@skill Athletics}) de DC 10 exitoso.

La torre tenía cuatro niveles con techos de 6 metros de altura; sin embargo, todos los niveles, excepto el más alto, tienen los suelos y los techos destrozados, y la escalera que subía por el interior de la torre, conectando sus distintos niveles, también ha sido destruida. La planta baja está ahora repleta de escombros helados a 6 metros de profundidad, y estos escombros impiden abrir la puerta de la planta baja.

entries.name: Balcony
entries: La mejor manera de entrar en la torre es a través del balcón. Sin embargo, se ha debilitado y se rompe si se colocan más de 150 libras de peso sobre él. La puerta que conduce desde el balcón no está cerrada con llave y se abre al nivel superior que sirve de cripta de Sandesyl. En este nivel no hay ventanas.

entries.name: Sandesyl's Crypt
entries: El ataúd de Sandesyl descansa en el centro del nivel superior de la torre, custodiado día y noche por sus dos consortes. El ataúd contiene tierra de la tumba, pero ningún tesoro. Una escalera de hielo abraza una de las paredes, desciende unos cuantos metros antes de terminar repentinamente, a 15 metros por encima del detritus helado que llena el nivel más bajo de la torre.

entries.name: 19. Steering Tower
entries: {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} ha asegurado la puerta de esta torre con un {@spell arcane lock}. Puede ser abierta normalmente por un gigante o por un hechizo de {@spell knock}. Para todos los demás, derribarla es prácticamente imposible, ya que se requiere un chequeo de Fuerza DC 70.

Una escalera de hielo conduce desde la planta baja de la torre a una cámara superior, cuyas paredes y techo brillan y resplandecen: Las joyas están por todas partes en la sala. Se ven piedras lunares resplandecientes, esmeraldas del tamaño de un pulgar, brillantes varitas de mithral plateadas y extrañas esferas cubiertas de turquesa y oro, así como docenas de palancas de cobre y esferas doradas incrustadas en las paredes. Al cabo de un momento, las propias paredes parecen desaparecer, proporcionando una vista aérea perfecta en todas las direcciones, como si no hubiera castillo ni nubes alrededor. Más de una docena de runas blancas resplandecientes cobran existencia, flotando por la habitación como copos de nieve.

Esta es la cámara de dirección del castillo. Cuando no hay nadie presente, el castillo está bajo el control del espíritu de Esclarotta, que está ligado a la fortaleza por una poderosa magia que no se puede disipar. Al tocar una de las runas brillantes se emite una orden específica al espíritu de Esclarotta. Un personaje que entienda el enano o el gigante puede interpretar las runas de mando.

entries.name: Command Runes
entries: Hay dieciocho runas de mando.

entries.name: Alarm
entries: Un ruido parecido a un viento aullante alerta a todas las criaturas no {@condition deafened} del castillo.

entries.name: All-Clear
entries: Un ruido parecido a un fuerte susurro señala el fin del peligro.

entries.name: Anchor
entries: El castillo mantiene su posición en el suelo o en el aire. El castillo permanece inmóvil a pesar de los vientos, las tormentas, etc.

entries.name: Calm
entries: Las nubes de tormenta que rodean el castillo disminuyen durante un periodo de 1 minuto. Durante este tiempo, la runa de la tormenta no se puede reactivar.

entries.name: Cast Off
entries: El castillo ya no está anclado.

entries.name: Drift
entries: El castillo va a la deriva con el viento, sin que nadie lo controle.

entries.name: Home
entries: El castillo vuelve a su lugar de origen, en la Espina del Mundo (una fría cordillera al norte).

entries.name: North, South, East, and West
entries: El castillo se mueve en la dirección cardinal especificada. Tocar dos runas simultáneamente puede mover el castillo en otras direcciones; por ejemplo, tocar las runas norte y este al mismo tiempo mueve el castillo hacia el noreste.

entries.name: Rise
entries: El castillo asciende a una velocidad de 3 metros por ronda.

entries.name: Sink
entries: El castillo desciende a una velocidad de 3 metros por asalto. Si entra en contacto con el suelo, aterriza.

entries.name: Spin
entries: El castillo gira suavemente en el sentido de las agujas del reloj, completando un giro completo en 1 minuto.

entries.name: Storm
entries: Las nubes que rodean el castillo se oscurecen y se agitan, convirtiéndose en estruendosos nubarrones durante 1 minuto. Hasta entonces, la runa de calma no puede ser activada. Una vez que las nubes de tormenta se han formado por completo, la criatura que activó la runa de tormenta puede utilizar su acción mientras está en la cámara de dirección para apuntar a una criatura que pueda ver con un rayo. El rayo tiene un alcance de 1.000 pies y puede apuntar a una criatura u objeto desatendido. Una criatura a la que se dirija el rayo debe tener éxito en una tirada de salvación de Destreza DC 14 o recibirá 22 ({@dice 4d10}) de daño por rayo. Un objeto desatendido que sea objetivo del rayo simplemente recibe el daño (sin tirada de salvación).

entries.name: Unveil
entries: La niebla que envuelve el castillo se disipa. Las zonas ligeramente oscurecidas se despejan en 1 asalto, y las zonas muy oscurecidas se oscurecen ligeramente durante 1 minuto y luego se despejan.

entries.name: Veil
entries: Unas nubes nebulosas se materializan alrededor del castillo. Al cabo de un minuto, todas las criaturas y objetos de las zonas exteriores en un radio de 30 metros del castillo quedan muy oscurecidos, y todas las criaturas y objetos de las zonas interiores quedan ligeramente oscurecidos.

entries.name: Widdershins
entries: El castillo gira suavemente en sentido contrario a las agujas del reloj, completando un giro completo en un minuto.

entries.name: Esclarotta
entries: Aunque cualquiera puede activar las runas de mando, el espíritu del gigante de las nubes Esclarotta controla en realidad el castillo y puede "bloquear" a los individuos que hacen un mal uso de las runas de mando, impidiéndoles activarlas.

Cualquier personaje que tenga éxito en un chequeo de Inteligencia DC 15 ({@skill Arcana}) percibe una inteligencia en funcionamiento, y uno puede intentar comunicarse con el espíritu de Esclarotta simplemente llamándolo mientras está dentro de la torre. Es un alma bondadosa, perturbada por los cultistas, el dragón, los wyverns y los kobolds que infestan su hermoso castillo, y anhela información sobre lo que su marido está tramando. Las peticiones que se le hacen tienen éxito con un chequeo de Carisma DC 14 ({@skill Persuasion}). La persona tiene ventaja en el chequeo si habla en gigante. Si alguien intenta destrozar la cámara de dirección, Esclarotta activa la runa de alarma. {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} (ver {@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12}) llega 3 asaltos después con dos {@creature Ogre||ogres} (sus mayordomos) a cuestas.
Si {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} muere a bordo del castillo, su espíritu sustituye al de Esclarotta, y estrella el castillo para evitar que caiga en manos del enemigo (ver "Avances").

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Si los personajes insisten en arrancar los valiosos elementos de control, pueden arrancar puñados de esmeraldas, turquesas, piedras lunares, un enorme trozo de jade, trozos de ámbar y grandes piezas de mithral, con un valor total de 10.000 gp.

Esto destruye la capacidad del castillo para moverse con energía, generar efectos meteorológicos, etc. El castillo irá a la deriva por los poderosos vientos que lo llevan hacia el norte, donde finalmente se estrella en el Glaciar Miklos en las Montañas del Espinazo del Mundo. La reparación del mecanismo de control requiere un largo período de trabajo extremadamente difícil y costoso, aunque un hechizo {@spell wish} podría lograrlo.

entries.name: Developments
entries: El castillo puede colapsar, dependiendo de las acciones de los personajes y de varios NPCs.

entries.name: Crashed by Blagothkus
entries: Si el gigante de las nubes es asesinado, el espíritu de su esposa en la cámara de dirección es sustituido por su espíritu. Enfurecido, vengará su muerte trasladando el castillo hacia el norte y ordenando que se estrelle en el Espinazo del Mundo, cerca del Glaciar Miklos. En {@adventure The Rise of Tiamat|RoT} se ofrecen más detalles sobre este accidente y sus consecuencias.

Si el dragón es asesinado y los cultistas son derrotados, {@creature Rath Modar|HotDQ} reúne las fuerzas restantes aliadas al culto y mata a {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ}, sabiendo perfectamente que la muerte del gigante de las nubes hará que el castillo se derrumbe (ver arriba). {@creature Rath Modar|HotDQ} utiliza entonces su hechizo {@spell fly} para escapar.

entries.name: Characters Seize the Castle
entries: Si los aventureros se hacen amigos de {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} y expulsan a los cultistas y al dragón, pueden llevarlo a cualquier parte, aunque seguramente atraerán la atención hostil de cualquier dragón. Si siguen a bordo del castillo, {@creature Rath Modar|HotDQ} y el vampiro hacen todo lo posible por frustrarlos.
Si permanece en el control del castillo, {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} decide visitar a los gigantes. Envía el castillo de Skyreach al norte, cerca de la Espina del Mundo.

entries.name: 20. Ogre Barracks
entries: Lee el siguiente texto si los personajes sorprenden a los ocupantes de esta cámara.
Esta cámara sin muebles contiene una horda de ogros que duermen sobre montones de pieles.

A menos que sean atraídos a otro lugar por una alarma o alguna otra perturbación, doce {@creature Ogre||ogres} duermen en las pieles amontonadas alrededor de esta estructura que, por lo demás, carece de características.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Todos los ogros guardan pequeñas cantidades de oro y plata en bolsas, sacos y cofres. Si los personajes dedican 30 minutos a registrar los barracones, encuentran 800 sp y 300 gp.
Si un miembro del grupo tiene éxito en un chequeo de Inteligencia ({@skill Investigation}) de DC 20, encuentra un único zafiro azul pálido valorado en 500 gp encajado en una grieta.

entries.name: Developments
entries: Si los ogros son tomados como prisioneros, {@condition charmed}, o hablados rápidamente, los personajes aprenden relativamente poco. Sirven al gigante de las nubes {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} (cuya esposa fue asesinada hace algunos años), saben que el gigante de las nubes tiene varios invitados, incluyendo "el mago de la túnica roja" ({@creature Rath Modar|HotDQ}), "la dama del dragón" ({@creature Rezmir|HotDQ}), y "un gran dragón blanco que vive en las cuevas" (Glazhael). Para obtener más que el resumen básico se requiere un chequeo de Carisma ({@skill Persuasion}) de DC 19 para cada uno de los siguientes tres elementos adicionales:

items: Un vampiro vigila el castillo de Skyreach por la noche. A veces se alimenta de los ogros, para su disgusto.

El culto utiliza el castillo para visitar lugares importantes sin caminos ni portales. Los ogros no saben realmente dónde están más que "los bosques verdes" y "esa extensión de los páramos" y "las viejas montañas".
La niebla y la navegación del castillo están controladas por la magia del gigante de las nubes. Sin él, el castillo no volará.

entries: El último punto es falso, pero es lo que {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} le dijo a sus ogros, y ellos le creen.

entries.name: 21. Esclarotta's Tomb
entries: Este quiste helado no tiene medios obvios de entrada o salida. Sin embargo, una criatura puede teletransportarse a esta cámara enterrada mediante {@area area 17|23c|x}.

Apareces en una cueva ovalada tallada en hielo glacial sólido, sin pasadizos de salida. El techo tiene nueve metros de altura y está recubierto de carámbanos, y los trozos de hielo rotos rodean un enorme sarcófago de mármol blanco situado en el centro del suelo. La tapa del sarcófago está esculpida con la imagen de un gigante femenino de larga cabellera.

El sarcófago mide 6 metros de largo, 3 metros de ancho y 3 metros de alto. Las runas enanas grabadas en su base deletrean el nombre ESCLAROTTA. La tapa del sarcófago requiere un chequeo de Fuerza DC 30 para empujarla, y los huesos de la difunta esposa del gigante de las nubes de {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} están contenidos dentro. No hay ningún tesoro enterrado con ella.
Una criatura de esta tumba que pronuncie el nombre "{@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ}" se teletransporta instantáneamente a la planta baja de {@area area 17|23c|x}.

entries.name: 22. Cloud Giant Tower
entries: Esta torre de 70 pies de altura tiene una azotea con parapeto, dos puertas sin llave a nivel del suelo y ninguna ventana. El interior de la torre está dividido en dos niveles, cada uno con un techo de 9 metros de altura. Una escalera de hielo cincelado abraza la pared interior y conecta ambos niveles.
A menos que los personajes den pasos para ocultar su aproximación, los ogros del tejado los detectan.

entries.name: Tower Rooftop
entries: Three {@creature Ogre||ogres} guard the tower rooftop, which is furnished with a ballista. See {@area area 6B|216|x} for details.

entries.name: Ground Floor
entries: A silver chime attached to the inside of each door rings whenever the door is opened, alerting the tower's inhabitants.

A staircase hugs the interior wall of this chamber, leading up to a landing with a door. The room itself contains sturdy wood-carved furnishings of giant proportions, including a table surrounded by four chairs. The walls are sculpted with ice murals depicting an army of hill, frost, fire, stone, and cloud giants.

Four {@creature Ogre||ogres} guard the lower level. They wear fancy plumed helmets to signify that they are members of {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ}'s "honor guard." This simple reward keeps the ogres alert and loyal, for they know the giant could give their helms away to someone else at any time.

entries.name: Upper Floor
entries: If the ogres above or below him sound the alarm, {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} cannot be surprised.

The walls of this room are sculpted with icy murals depicting cloud giants riding giant birds. An enormous bed with a headboard of ice sculpted to resemble clouds dominates the room. Bear furs are heaped upon the bed, and two large wooden chests rest at the bed's foot.
A blue-skinned giant sits on the floor with his legs crossed while two ogres comb his snowy white hair. The giant's hulking morningstar leans against the bed within arm's reach.

{@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} ({@adventure appendix D|HotDQ|12}) and the two {@creature Ogre||ogres} (his stewards) aren't the only inhabitants of this room. As a bonus action on his turn, {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} can summon an {@creature air elemental} that's been magically bound to the room. The elemental follows the giant's commands but cannot leave the room. It remains until dismissed by its master.

The dim-witted ogre stewards are poor conversationalists, but {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} uses them as sounding boards, expressing his concerns that the Cult of the Dragon might try to seize control of the castle. The ogres offer no advice. Clever characters can sow discord by preying on the giant's fears (see "{@area Negotiating with the Cloud Giant|20d|x}" near the beginning of the chapter). An alarm or the characters' sudden appearance startles him, and he reaches for his weapon. If the characters are pretending to be cultists, {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} is furious at their intrusion but does not attack unless they further provoke him. The ogres defend their master to the death.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chests are unlocked and loaded with silver and gold coins (12,000 gp total). One of the chests also contains a {@item bag of holding}, four bars of solid gold (worth 1,000 gp each), and forty bars of solid silver (worth 100 gp each). Each bar weighs approximately 5 pounds.

entries.name: Developments
entries: If the characters surrender to {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ}, he asks about their names, allegiances, and plans. If the characters represent themselves as enemies of the cult, the giant says, "I can take care of them. But just in case, you should know that they are entirely serious about making dragons a power along the coast again. Can you imagine? The nerve." If they sway the giant to their side, he locks himself in {@area area 19|243|x} and guides the castle northward while the characters deal with the cultists and the white dragon. {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ}'s ultimate destination is described in {@adventure The Rise of Tiamat|RoT}.

If anyone attempts to wrest the castle from him, {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} goes to the steering tower and tries to crash the castle in the Spine of the World; see area 19 for details. If {@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} is killed, his spirit takes over the castle, with the same end result.

entries.name: 23. Giant Guest Chambers
entries: These rooms are set aside for giant-sized guests and have furnishings of the appropriate size.
In each room, a large section of the outer wall vanishes for 1 minute when touched, revealing a icy landing platform. Long ago, giants would use these platforms to land their flying roc mounts.

entries.name: 24. Servant Barracks
entries: Twenty {@creature Kobold||kobolds} are trying to sleep here on dozens of small piles of bedding, fur, and clothes. They are exhausted and ignore the characters unless they are in great danger. They have no treasure.
Characters questioning the kobold servants may make a DC 12 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. If the characters are dressed as cultists and are fairly convincing, no check is required.

Each success brings one of the following bits of information to light; the first failure by any character means that the kobolds unite in their terror of the cultists and go completely silent. If questioned further, they start screaming for help and babbling for mercy: completely useless.

items: An elf vampire lives in the crumbling tower ({@area area 18|23f|x}).
{@creature Blagothkus|HotDQ} still speaks to his dead wife, and her spirit is the castle's pilot and protector. If the giant dies, all the magic of the castle will be undone.

The human dragon-cult people don't really understand dragons the way that kobolds do. Dragons are fine creatures, but grumpy. They say the treasure here is for the queen of all dragons, to keep her from being grumpy.
A red-robed wizard is working with the cultists, and his room ({@area area 12|22d|x}) is off limits to all kobolds.
The white dragon Cloudchaser loves frozen meat. Toss it into the cavern (area 25) and run!

entries.name: 25. Main Vault
entries: The icy "core" of the castle is hollowed out with tunnels that break the surface at multiple points. The white dragon, Glazhael the Cloudchaser, enters and leaves via a wide funnel-shaped passageway that narrows as it draws closer to the main vault, where the Cult of the Dragon stores its treasure.
If the characters explore the tunnels, read or paraphrase the following:

The walls of blue ice are partly transparent, revealing various things embedded in the ice all around, including coins, helmets, livestock, a handful of kobolds, and an ogre or two. Frost coats the tunnel floors and crunches underfoot.
When the characters reach the main vault, read:

All tunnels seem to lead to a central core—a glittering cavern of ice with jagged walls and icicles the size of stalactites. This grand vault is split into two levels: an egg-shaped upper level with a sheer ledge overlooking a sunken level 30 feet below, where a massive pile of treasure rests beneath an icy glaze. Clinging to the ceiling above the hoard, wings tucked in tight along its sides with claws gripping the ice, is a huge white dragon.

Glazhael is an {@creature adult white dragon} that is doing his part to ensure the rise of Tiamat, hopeful that the queen of evil dragons will reward him with untold power. He is, however, a bit on the dim side, thinking of visitors as either servants (who bring him food) or as enemies (who do not bring him food). Mostly, Glazhael is proud to guard this treasure for Tiamat, his most glorious and perfect queen. He rarely talks to any cultists other than Talis and is suspicious of {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ} and the others.
If the characters speak with Glazhael, he responds with a pompous speech about the superiority of dragons over humans, dwarves, and so forth.

If the characters flatter him to a ludicrous degree, he listens to anything that sounds like fawning, servile, helpful obedience but offers nothing in return. He will generously spare the lives of those who offer him tribute in the form of treasure or food. Those who challenge him become targets of his breath weapon.

When fighting, Glazhael clings to the ceiling whenever possible, using his breath weapon and Frightful Presence to start. If that doesn't scare the characters off, he makes melee attacks until his breath weapon recharges. If dropped to fewer than 40 hit points, he flees. He can navigate even the narrow tunnels by tucking in his wings. Once outside, he alerts the rest of the castle, shouting "They're after the treasure!" in Draconic.
Clever characters can lure the dragon into a narrow tunnel where it is unable to maneuver effectively. Under such circumstances, the dragon has disadvantage on its melee attacks.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: When the characters investigate the hoard, read:
The floor of the cavern is carpeted in gold, silver, copper, and jewels, all sealed under a sheet of ice. Dozens of old human skulls and bones are also frozen in the ice.

The treasure hoard is frozen in ice, and it requires either several fire spells or a long wait with bonfires to melt the ice. The hoard includes 500,000 cp, 100,000 sp, and 5,000 gp, a frozen chest containing 800 pp and 21 small blue sapphires worth 300 gp each, a frozen {@item potion of gaseous form}, a {@item +1 longsword}, a {@item +1 longbow}, {@item +1 leather armor}, and {@item bracers of defense}.

entries.name: Developments
entries: If the dragon is slain, the cultists are enraged and seek immediate vengeance. The major cult players on Skyreach Castle will call out the ogres, wake the vampire, and ask the Red Wizards to find the intruders. If the characters are still around after the dragon is slain, the entire castle is on high alert until they are found and killed.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: The crash or capture of Skyreach Castle marks the end of {@i Hoard of the Dragon Queen}. If you are using the milestone experience rule, the characters reach 8th level for completing the adventure. By uncovering the cult's plans and hijacking a huge hoard of treasure, the characters have slowed and damaged the cult's chances of success. They may also have slain or captured important leaders of the Cult of the Dragon. But there is much more to come. The cult moves forward with its plan to free their five-headed queen out of the Nine Hells, and the mere loss of wealth will not stop the true fanatics.

{@adventure The Rise of Tiamat|RoT} expands on the final drive to destroy the Cult of the Dragon, and it requires great new powers and new courage. Things grow much more dangerous for the adventurers as they seek help in strange places, from the Sea of Moving Ice to the depths of the Serpent Hills. They might find a great weapon among the giants or uncover an unexpected ally within the cult itself.

Unless the characters press on, the Queen of Dragons might yet establish her personal rule over the lands of lesser creatures. The stakes are high when the gates to the Nine Hells open, and scaly doom comes out of its lair, full of fire and fangs.
The conflict reaches its apex at the Well of Dragons, where the characters and their hard-won allies face Tiamat and her greatest minions in a fight to the death!

data.name: Appendix A: Backgrounds
entries: This appendix provides players with an easy way to create characters with compelling ties to the events of Tyranny of Dragons.

entries.name: Background Template
entries: Below is a background template that applies to any background that you select or create. You can replace or augment some or all of the options in your chosen background with one or more of the elements given below. Each section tells you whether it replaces or adds to your background.

entries.name: The Story Thus Far...
entries: As the Cult of the Dragon has grown bolder, its actions have drawn attention. Your character has stumbled into the Cult's scheme in some manner or has a connection to dragons. The following tables provide you with bonds tailored to this campaign. Use them in place of or in addition to the ones you selected from (or created for) your background.

rows: {@creature Leosin Erlanthar|HotDQ}, a wandering monk, once saved your life. He's sent urgent word for you to meet him in a small town called Greenest. Looks like it's time to pay off that debt.
When an orc raid drove your family from your home, the people of Greenest took you in. Anyone who threatens Greenest is your sworn enemy.

Every five nights, you have a strange sequence of apocalyptic dreams. The world is destroyed by cold, choking fumes, lightning storms, waves of acid, and horrible fire. Each time, the dream ends with ten evil eyes glaring at you from the darkness. You feel a strange compulsion to travel to Greenest. Perhaps the answer to the riddle of your dreams awaits you there.
{@creature Ontharr Frume|HotDQ}, a crusading warrior and champion of good, is your friend and mentor. He has asked you to travel to Greenest in search of rumors of increasing dragon activity.

You have heard rumors that your close childhood friend, a half-elf named Talis, has been kidnapped by a strange group of dragon cultists. Your investigations into the cult have led you to the town of Greenest. You must save her!

Being the grandchild of a renowned dragon slayer is usually a good way to impress people, but just last week a gang of ruffians attack you. You barely escaped with your life, but as you fled, the ruffians told you that the Cult of the Dragon never forgets and always avenges. You're hoping to lie low in a sleepy little town called Greenest until this blows over.

On his deathbed, your father confessed that he had become involved with a group called the Cult of the Dragon. They paid him to smuggle goods across the Sword Coast. Wracked by guilt, he begged you to investigate the cult and undo the evil he may have helped foster. He urged you to begin your search in a town called Greenest.

The dragons destroyed everything you hold dear. They killed your family and destroyed your home. Now, with nothing but what you carry on your back and a horrid scar of the near fatal wounds you sustained in the attack, you seek revenge.

You and your family were members of the Cult of the Dragon, until your rivals in the cult arranged to wipe you out. Though they slaughtered your kin, you survived, but they think you're dead. Now is your chance for vengeance! Your hit list consists of three names: a human cultist named {@creature Frulam Mondath|HotDQ}, a half-orc named Bog Luck, and a half-dragon named {@creature Rezmir|HotDQ}. You have arrived in Greenest, knowing it's next on the cult's list of targets.

You have a secret. You once were a gold dragon who served Bahamut. You were too proud and vain, to the point that Bahamut decided to teach you a lesson. You have been trapped in a weak, humanoid body, with your memories of your former life but a dim shadow. You remember only one thing with perfect clarity: Bahamut's command to go into the world and prove your devotion to the cause of good. If you prove worthy, on your death you will return to his side in your true form.

data.name: Appendix E: Concept Gallery
entries: Just as most adventurers don't walk into a dragon's lair without a plan, neither were D&D's iconic monsters developed without considerable forethought. This gallery explores some of the behind-the-scenes development that went into creating {@i Tyranny of Dragons}, as well as defining a spectrum of monsters, allies, and enemies that would feature in Dungeons & Dragons offerings for years to come.

On the following pages, you'll find a number of images designed to serve as story beats in the larger {@i Tyranny of Dragons} campaign. These images were created to define impactful moments in a hypothetical {@i Tyranny of Dragons} tale, one which then could be explored by multiple teams over the course of multiple projects—be they games, fiction, or otherwise. Some elements you'll recognize from the events of the {@i Tyranny of Dragons} adventures, while others were meant to provide inspiration for events parallel stories could detail.

Beyond these, this gallery also includes a number of designs focused on threats integral to the {@i Tyranny of Dragons} campaign. This includes explorations of well-known Forgotten Realms villains, like the Cult of the Dragon and the Red Wizards of Thay. The images herein show just a few avenues explored in updating these foes to the most current edition of the game, along with notes taken from internal concept and story documents. Some present ideas never fully expressed in {@i Tyranny of Dragons}, while others reveal deeper depths to adventure elements hiding whole conceptual icebergs. Certain components central to the adventure also see extensive exploration, like the garb of the Red Wizards, the iconography of the Cult of the Dragon, and—of course—the multiple deadly aspects of one of the campaign's central magic items, the {@item Mask of the Dragon Queen|RoT}.

Several other locations and characters also feature prominently in this collection, many being aspects of the Forgotten Realms or underpinning the wider D&D multiverse that have seen artistic evolutions over the years. The thorough design sketches of chromatic dragons, for example, hint at the depth of ecological detail that's gone into realizing D&D's most iconic monsters—and foes central to the {@i Tyranny of Dragons} plot.

How you choose to use this concept gallery is up to you. Perhaps these details will inspire you, just as they did the original {@i Tyranny of Dragons} designers. Maybe a particular image will resound with you, leading you to make your own addition to the wider campaign. Added insights on the tools and techniques of the adventure's villains can help you make them feel like more vital inhabitants of a wider world, while nuances of dragons and other can creatures aid in bringing these terrors to life. These pages might also be shared with players as you see fit, driving home the impact of the campaign's most climatic moments. Whether this gallery serves as a game aide or inspires your own designs, use it as you please, further detailing the existing adventures or exploring {@i Tyranny of Dragons} stories yet to be told!

entries.name: Red Wizards
entries: Red Wizards are the would-be magical overlords of Faerûn.
Feared by the general public as evil tyrants, Red Wizards trade their magical inventions for slaves, steel, silk, and gold.
As magical artificers of great skill, they command high prices, and are not afraid to extend credit—for there are few who could survive an unpaid debt to these wizards.

entries.name: The Black Network
entries: Agents of the Black Network have winged snake companions that serve as messengers. Members of the Zhentarim use these creatures to deliver messages on scrolls and stay in contact with one another. A winged snake is trained to serve a particular master. If its master dies, the snake has been known to remain nearby and starve to death.

images.title: Dread Warriors make up the terrifying undead army of the Red Wizards
Zhentarim, also known as the Black Network, and winged snake

entries.name: Dread Warriors
entries: Created from the freshly dead bodies of skilled warriors, dread warriors are especially formidable zombie-like creatures, retaining some of their intelligence and much of the fighting skill they possessed in life.
No race is immune from being transformed into a dread warrior. Once set upon a task, these undead will do nothing—will not pause or turn aside—until they've fulfilled their orders.

entries.name: Dragon Masks
entries: A dragon mask enhances a person's ability to communicate with dragons of a particular color.
If the wearer is exceptionally well versed in the behavior and mannerisms of the appropriate color dragon, the mask allows the wearer to become a "dragon whisperer."
Dragon masks allow the wearer to think like a dragon of the appropriate color, influence those dragons, and gain their favor. This ability is crucial to keeping dragons aligned with the cult.
The five dragon masks can be combined in a ritual to form the supreme Mask of the Dragon Queen.
The wearer of this mask can channel its power to beckon Tiamat from her infernal realm, although she does so willingly—not because the mask compels her.

entries.name: Temple of Tiamat
entries: The Cult of the Dragon seeks to raise Tiamat's temple from the Nine Hells, bringing it into being inside the caldera of an ancient volcano known as the Well of Dragons. From this bulwark, who knows what dire destruction the Queen of Evil Dragons might visit upon the realms?

entries.name: Icewind Dale
entries: The farthest north region along the Sword Coast, Icewind Dale is an unforgiving land where the rugged inhabitants of ten small towns dedicate themselves to carving a living from the ice and snow.
The drow elf Drizzt Do'Urden numbers among the land's most legendary heroes.

entries.name: Waterdeep
entries: The City of Splendors is the greatest of the Sword Coast cities. Home to as many as two million residents, Waterdeep is a stable and generally peaceful city. Still, there are parts of Waterdeep that can be dangerous for the unwary, such as the rough-and-tumble Dock Ward.

entries.name: People of the Sword Coast
entries: Numerous people make their homes along the Sword Coast.
Whether commoners or nobles, trades folk or adventurers, all have much to lose at the hands of the Cult of the Dragon, but also the potential for great heroism.

entries.name: Red Dragons
entries: Red dragons are vain, reflected in their proud, upright bearing and disdainful expression.
Their pupils fade as they age, until the oldest have eyes with the appearance of molten orbs.
An angry red may have flames licking up from eyes and nostrils—and an envelope of heat-shimmer around them.
Their frill and wings are an ashy blue or purple grey toward the edges, becoming darker with ages—nearly black on older specimens.
Reds smell like smoke and sulphur.

entries.name: Blue Dragons
entries: Blues are vain and territorial.
They are distinguished by their dramatic frilled ears and single, massive brow horn. They are also one of the best-adapted dragon breeds for digging into sand.
Their hides tend to hum and crackle faintly with built-up static electricity, and to emit small arcs of electricity. These effects intensify when the dragon is angry or about to attack.
They smell of ozone + sand.

entries.name: Black Dragons
entries: Black dragons are evil-tempered, cunning, and, malevolent. Their crafty, sinister faces reflect this.

They are sometimes known as "skull dragons" for their deeply socketed eyes and distinctinve nasal opening. Adding to this impression is the gradual deterioration of the hide around the horn base/cheekbone. This does no harm to the dragon but increases with age.

entries.name: White Dragons
entries: Among the smallest and least intelligent of dragonkind, most white dragons are simply animalistic predators.
Their faces express a hunter's single-mindedness and ferocity rather than the shrewdness and insight of the more powerful evil dragons.
Their beaked, crested heads are distinctive.
(A crisp, faintly chemical odor).
